channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: China’s Weak Currency Is Powering Its Exports and Drawing Criticism
item.description: China’s renminbi is lagging the currencies of key trading partners, making Chinese goods and services cheap and helping to drive exports.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: An advertisement for a Xiaomi 17 Pro phone next to an Apple store in Shanghai. The weak value of the Chinese currency has hurt the ability of Chinese consumers to afford foreign brands.

item.title: China’s Trade Surplus Climbs Past $1 Trillion for First Time
item.description: President Trump’s tariffs weren’t enough to hold back the global export flood by China, which pushed past last year’s record in just 11 months.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Geely manufacturing plant in Hangzhou, China. Carmakers and other exporters in traditional manufacturing powerhouses like Germany, Japan and South Korea are losing customers to Chinese rivals.

item.title: Bessent Says He Divested From Soybean Farms After Ethics Office Warning
item.description: The Treasury Secretary said on Sunday he recently shed his holdings to comply with his federal ethics agreement.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: China stopped buying American soybeans in response to President Trump’s tariffs, inflicting economic pain on U.S. farmers.

item.title: Dario Amodei on the Risk of an A.I. Bubble, Regulation and A.G.I.
item.description: The Anthropic chief executive spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler
item.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
item.media:description: Andrew interviewing Dario Amodei, the C.E.O. of Anthropic, at the 2025 DealBook Summit.

item.title: Netflix Deal for Warner Bros. Adds New Twist to Rivalry With HBO
item.description: Netflix’s blockbuster deal to buy Warner Bros., including HBO, is the latest twist in a rivalry that has reshaped the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ted Sarandos, now co-chief executive officer of Netflix, recently recalled his reaction to HBO’s refusal in 2010 to license its shows: Netflix had to make original programs of its own.

item.title: Social Security at 70? Why the Gold Standard Advice Works for Only a Few
item.description: The standard advice is to hold off, but most retirees claim the benefit as soon as they can, at age 62. Here’s what to know when you’re planning the unplannable.
item.dc:creator: Brian J. O’Connor
item.media:credit: Richard Beaven for The New York Times
item.media:description: Blair Barondes and his wife, Janet Bowdan, calculated that waiting until 70 to take Social Security wouldn’t net them more over their retirement.

item.title: A Data Center Wrapped in a Mystery Comes to the New Mexican Desert
item.description: As wealthier areas are pushing back against huge A.I. data centers, speculators are pitching places like Doña Ana County, N.M., on their vision. Local officials are eager for a deal — even if they don’t quite know the terms.
item.dc:creator: David Segal

item.title: With MaXhosa Africa, Laduma Ngxokolo Is Reweaving South Africa’s Story
item.description: Laduma Ngxokolo, the designer behind MaXhosa Africa, is on a mission to embrace his country’s history and traditions, rather than hide from them.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: Laduma Ngxokolo founded MaXhosa Africa in 2010, basing the label’s offerings on traditional Xhosa patterns and motifs, but reimagined for the modern world.

item.title: Crayola Magnetic Blocks Are Recalled Over Choking Hazard Concerns
item.description: Magnets in the toy, pip-Cubes, can fall out of the blocks and be swallowed by children, causing injury or death, federal regulators warned.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: via Crayola
item.media:description: CreateOn, which imports the pip-Cubes toys, said that there have been reports of three cases of magnets falling out of the blocks.

item.title: Scott Bessent on Tariffs, the Fed and the Economy
item.description: The U.S. treasury secretary spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew interviews U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent at the 2025 DealBook Summit.

item.title: What to Know About Netflix’s $83 Billion Deal for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: The cash-and-stock deal would give the world’s largest paid streaming service expansive power over theater owners and entertainment-industry unions.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Jae C. Hong/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Warner Bros. studios in Burbank, Calif.

item.title: Angst Turns to Anger in Hollywood as Netflix Hooks Warner Bros.
item.description: Much of the entertainment capital fears that Netflix’s deal will lead to more job losses and theater closings and fewer boundary-pushing movies.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Netflix insisted on Friday that it would follow the Warner Bros. model and continue to release movies in theaters for exclusive runs. But many people in Hollywood were skeptical.

item.title: Trump Accounts, Baby Bonds: Giving Directly to Kids Is an Idea Right and Left Could Love
item.description: Michael and Susan Dell’s $6.25 billion donation to child savings accounts fits a trend: giving with no strings attached. In some ways, it’s a bipartisan philosophy.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with Michael and Susan Dell announcing their donation to child savings accounts on Tuesday.

item.title: Have Trump’s Tariffs Gone as High as They Can Go? Businesses Hope So
item.description: A wave of companies are petitioning for exemptions from the Trump administration’s high levies on foreign-made goods, saying they are hurting business and raising prices.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Adam Kuehl for The New York Times

item.title: Don’t Call It a Pivot. These Executives Are ‘Refounding’ Their Start-Ups.
item.description: In the age of artificial intelligence, some company leaders are framing new business lines as radical reboots.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Cristina Spanò

item.title: Survivors of the Deadly Hong Kong Fire Are in Limbo
item.description: Hong Kong, with some of the world’s highest housing costs and inequality, must now figure out how to help thousands of residents who lost friends, family and homes.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Theodora Yu and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Associated Press
item.media:description: Wang Fuk Court, a residential estate in the Tai Po district of Hong Kong, after a blaze damaged the complex late last month.

item.title: Chuck Kesey, Probiotic Yogurt Pioneer, Dies at 87
item.description: The younger brother of Ken Kesey, the novelist and counterculture luminary, he turned a defunct creamery into what is now Nancy’s Probiotic Foods.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Olivia Nuzzi and Vanity Fair Will Part Ways
item.description: Condé Nast, the magazine’s parent company, said her contract would expire at the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: New claims about Olivia Nuzzi, who was named Vanity Fair’s West Coast editor in September, have arisen over her past relationship with Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

item.title: Lots of Oil, Little Production: What to Know About Venezuelan Energy
item.description: The South American country increasingly at odds with the Trump administration has the world’s largest oil reserves.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Lazaro Gamio
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Netflix Changes Course Again With Warner Bros. Deal
item.description: The streaming giant has changed its strategy many times over the years. But the decision to get deeply into theatrical releases may be the most startling yet.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Carl Godfrey; Source Photographs via Getty

item.title: CNN Is Excluded From Netflix’s Warner Bros. Deal for Now
item.description: The prospect of Paramount’s buying Warner Bros. Discovery had led CNN journalists to wonder if the channel may be combined with CBS News. Instead, CNN will remain in a separate corporate entity.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Kevin Carter/Getty Images
item.media:description: A CNN sign outside the network’s studios in Washington.

item.title: Versace Announces Dario Vitale’s Shocking Departure
item.description: After one hit collection, the designer Dario Vitale will be leaving the brand. What’s going on?
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: Elon Musk Loves What Mario Nawfal Has to Say
item.description: Mario Nawfal has a knack for getting Mr. Musk’s attention online, and for turning that into big business.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger
item.media:credit: Katarina Premfors for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mario Nawfal in his home in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. A Lebanese Australian entrepreneur, he draws engagement from Elon Musk on X like nobody else.

item.title: PCE Report Shows Consumer Prices Rose Slightly in September
item.description: The most recent Personal Consumption Expenditures index was delayed because of the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Economists remain split on whether the worst of the price increases has passed, or if there is more pain to come.

item.title: The Markets Are Temperamental. Understand Your Risks.
item.description: Shifting expectations of a Fed rate cut reflect underlying uncertainty about politics and the economy. Here are some essentials for managing risk in investing.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:credit: Giulio Bonasera

item.title: More Disabled People Can Open Special Savings Accounts. Do You Qualify?
item.description: Starting next year, people who became disabled by age 46 will be eligible for ABLE accounts. The accounts have been slow to catch on, partly because the current age limit is 26.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: New York Times Sues A.I. Start-Up Perplexity Over Use of Copyrighted Work
item.description: Filed in federal court on Friday, the suit joins more than 40 other court disputes between copyright holders and A.I. companies.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
item.media:description: The A.I. start-up Perplexity, led by Aravind Srinivas, has also been sued by Dow Jones, the owner of The Wall Street Journal.

item.title: Why the Battle for Warner Bros. Discovery May Not Be Over Yet
item.description: Netflix struck a deal to buy one of Hollywood’s most storied studios. But a scorned rival, and the Trump administration, may put up a fight.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Grady McGregor
item.media:credit: Mike Blake/Reuters
item.media:description: The fierce bidding war for Warner Bros. Discovery has taken a decisive turn.

item.title: India’s IndiGo Airline Falls Into Chaos, Canceling About 1,000 Flights
item.description: IndiGo, which controls nearly two-thirds of the domestic market, blamed the disruption on weather, tech systems and rules about rest for crew members. Pilots said the company was cutting corners.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Priyanshu Singh/Reuters
item.media:description: Stranded passengers at an airport in Bengaluru, India, on Friday.

item.title: How Scammers Target Older Americans With Fraudulent Medicare Calls
item.description: Complaints about the calls have risen, and some older Americans have discovered that their Medicare accounts were already compromised.
item.dc:creator: Nick Keppler
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Kurutz, 80, has been receiving up to 60 Medicare scam calls a day.

item.title: How Batteries Got Cheaper and Made the Electric Grid More Reliable
item.description: An early grid battery was installed in the Atacama Desert in Chile 15 years ago. Now, as prices have tumbled, they are increasingly being used around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Employees working on battery units at the solar project, which is owned by AES, a Virginia company that holds utilities and power plants across the world.

item.title: Netflix to Buy Warner Bros in $83 Billion Deal
item.description: The deal to acquire the Hollywood behemoth’s television and film studios as well as HBO Max will bulk up the world’s biggest paid streaming service.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes, Lauren Hirsch and Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: Netflix has never tried an acquisition even remotely close to this size.

item.title: Stellantis Is in Default for Moving Jeep Production to U.S., Canada Says
item.description: The automaker switched production from Ontario in a bid to please President Trump. But the company defaulted on contracts covering hundreds of millions of dollars in assistance, Canada said.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stellantis’s plant in Brampton, Canada. The European-based automaker also produces vehicles under the Chrysler, Dodge and Ram brands in North America.

item.title: Faulty Glucose Monitor Sensors May Be Tied to 7 Deaths, F.D.A. Says
item.description: Abbott Diabetes Care said it had received reports of more than 700 injuries that may be associated with malfunctioning sensors.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Groups Express Anixety as Trump Threatens to Derail U.S.-Mexico-Canada Trade Pact
item.description: Hearings that began Wednesday in Washington reflected anxiety over the future of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade pact and whether the president could end up scrapping it.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Though President Trump negotiated and signed the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, he said this year that he wanted to make it a “much better deal.”

item.title: Newsom, Kirk, A.I., Trump and Other DealBook Summit Highlights
item.description: The economy, inflation, tariffs, bubble fears, crypto and other big topics that made headlines this year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gavin Newsom, the governor of California, voiced his criticism of President Trump — and the business world’s deepening ties to his administration.

item.title: Harvey, a Maker of A.I. Legal Software, Raises $160 Million
item.description: The start-up is now valued at about $8 billion as it pushes to add new customers, including those outside law firms.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced

item.title: But Who Is the Snake in ‘Zootopia 2’?
item.description: Gary Goldman, who has battled Disney in court over the franchise, thinks the viper Gary De’Snake is based on him.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes

item.title: New York Times Sues Pentagon Over First Amendment Rights
item.description: The lawsuit said the Defense Department’s new set of rules for journalists “violates the Constitution’s guarantees of due process, freedom of speech and freedom of the press.”
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: A new set of press restrictions at the Pentagon took effect in October.

item.title: A Growing U.S. Tech Hub Needs Workers. Colleges Try to Keep Up.
item.description: The success of efforts to turn Phoenix into a dominant center of semiconductor manufacturing may hinge on efforts to train local workers.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gowning area at Arizona State University’s student-operated semiconductor factory.

item.title: 18,000 Reasons It’s So Hard to Build a Chip Factory in America
item.description: The transformation of Phoenix into a semiconductor hub by Taiwan’s TSMC illustrates the difficulties of large-scale projects in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman and Loren Elliott
item.media:description: Kathy Bartelheim worried that a proposed Amkor Technology factory would interfere with the peace and solitude of her home near Phoenix.

item.title: In Arizona Desert, Taiwanese Families Create Community and Build a Factory
item.description: Skilled workers from Taiwan engaged in the chip industry have found ways to ease the transition to America while making an imprint on Greater Phoenix.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharon Lee, ordering at a Taiwanese restaurant in Phoenix, moved to Arizona two years ago with her husband, who works for Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, and their young twins.

item.title: Erika Kirk Takes on the Mantle of Leading Turning Point USA
item.description: The widow of Charlie Kirk promoted conciliation and portrayed her late husband as a seeker of dialogue.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: 5 Takeaways From the 2025 DealBook Summit
item.description: President Trump’s economic policies and artificial intelligence were among the central topics at the gathering of business and political leaders.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone, Brian O’Keefe and Bernhard Warner
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, right, speaking to Andrew Ross Sorkin, Dealbook Editor at Large, at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Newsom Warns That Trump Is ‘Trying to Wreck This Country’
item.description: The California governor weighed in on the 2028 presidential election, and called out executives for “bending the knee” to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: For MrBeast, YouTube Still Rules, but It’s Not Everything
item.description: The social media star has created a vast and varied business empire with big expansion plans.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jimmy Donaldson, known as MrBeast, at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Netanyahu Says He Is Undaunted by Legal Woes at Home and Threats of Arrest by New York’s Mayor-Elect
item.description: Netanyahu says he is undaunted by Mamdani arrest threats or domestic legal woes
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel speaking at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday via video from Israel.
